author: Andy Anderson
bottom_line: The avalanche danger will rise quickly today with new snow and wind up high and rain down low. Watch out for open slopes near ridges and gullies with fresh slabs of wind-blown snow, steep slopes in sheltered areas where storm snow piles up, and any places where rain falls on snow. Stepping back into simpler, less steep terrain away from steep slopes can help avoid today's avalanche problems.
hazard_discussion:
• Yesterday observers reported some softening on sunny SE-S-SW aspects by midday. Other aspects and shady areas on the southerly aspects remained firm and frozen. Some of the northerly aspects still have a dusting of soft snow on top of the crusts. 
  • Observers reported graupel and surface hoar on the snow surface in some areas yesterday.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
SW winds will pile new snow onto leeward-facing slopes near ridges, open wind-exposed slopes, and gullies. New wind slabs will form faster than they can bond to the firm snow surfaces below. They may start small, but they will quickly grow in size and extent as new snow accumulates. People will likely trigger wind slab avalanches on steep slopes where wind-blown snow piles up, and natural avalanches may be possible in areas with intense wind loading. The most fragile wind slabs will form on near and above treeline NW-N-NE-E-SE aspects. New fragile cornices will also form along many ridges. 

Conditions will change fast today and the same slope that did not show signs of instability early in the day could produce a wind slab avalanche large enough to cause problems a short while later. Recent avalanches, blowing snow, cracking in wind-blown snow, and new cornices indicate the presence of unstable wind slabs.  Blowing snow will also decrease visibility and make identifying avalanche terrain more difficult today. Traveling in terrain sheltered from the winds can help avoid the wind slabs and should also provide more consistent snow quality.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Rising snow levels and rapid accumulation will allow storm slab avalanches to become likely today. In addition to the weaknesses that form within the storm snow, the new snow may have trouble bonding to the existing snow surfaces, especially if the new snow accumulates on top of yesterday's surface hoar. Like the wind slabs mentioned above, these storm slabs should start out small and quickly increase in size and distribution as the storm intensifies. By midday, unstable storm slabs could exist on any steep slope including below treeline slopes and other typically sheltered areas.

Look for cracking in the storm snow and feel for different layers of snow as you travel through the terrain.  If you see any signs of storm snow weakness or doubt a slope's stability, move to lower-angle, non-avalanche terrain.

media.title: Storm slab avalanche on lower Trestle Peak.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: As snow levels rise this afternoon, rain will fall on fresh snow and cause wet loose avalanche activity on steep slopes. Many of these wet snow instabilities would remain small, but they could still cause problems, and terrain traps like gullies, cliffs, or creeks would amplify the potential consequences. Longer slopes could produce larger wet loose avalanches.
forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.
